title: 107_hr4155
content: The Act titled "District of Columbia Legislative Autonomy Act of 2002" eliminates congressional review of newly-passed District laws. The District of Columbia Home Rule Act is amended to remove congressional review of newly-passed District laws. Section 602 and 604 are struck, and the exercise of rulemaking power is clarified. The House of Representatives and the Senate have the power to make rules, which will supersede other rules if inconsistent. Each House can change its rules at any time, similar to the process for any other changes. The House of Representatives and the overnment can change its rules at any time, similar to the process for any other changes. SEC. 3. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. The District of Columbia Home Rule Act is amended by removing certain subsections and sentences, as well as striking specific phrases in different sections. The District of Columbia Home Rule Act is amended by removing subsections, striking phrases, and modifying sections related to payments not subject to appropriation for revenue anticipation notes. The District of Columbia Home Rule Act is amended to clarify that payments for revenue anticipation notes are not subject to appropriation. Additionally, other laws related to initiative and referendum procedures are modified. The District of Columbia Home Rule Act is amended to clarify that payments for revenue anticipation notes are not subject to appropriation. Section 5 of Amendment No. 1 to title IV of the District Charter is also amended regarding initiative and referendum procedures. The District of Columbia Home Rule Act is amended to clarify payment for revenue anticipation notes. Amendment No. 1 to title IV of the District Charter is also amended regarding initiative and referendum procedures. Section 404 is modified by removing certain sentences and subsection (m) is revised for clarity. The amendments made by this Act, effective from October 1, 2002, apply to acts of the District of Columbia passed by the Council and signed by the Mayor, vetoed by the Mayor and repassed by the Council, passed by the Council and allowed to become effective without the Mayor's signature, or ratified by a majority of registered qualified electors for initiated acts and acts subject to referendum.
